text:
Hey folks, I'm Aria :wave:

Like most people here, I daydream FOC ideas :smile: I'm usually thinking about the gaps that separate groups of people, and how tools and languages can bridge those gaps.

I've been _trying_ to do this as my job since 2014, but only managed to get there three years ago. I've been funding it with consulting, grants, and two very helpful angel investors.

What I'm working on is an authoring environment where developers and designers make things together. I usually describe it as a design tool that "blurs the line between designer/developer, author/consumer, and artist/scientist." If that sounds lofty, it's because it is. Right now it's just a modest animation editor for web apps that can be used by both designers and developers.

Short-term, it scratches an old itch. I always wanted to draw and code the same kind of stuff.

Long-term, I think this kind of environment (one that bridges manual and procedural creation), can be a building block to other FOC applications, like data/interactive journalism, exploratory learning, and trans-disciplinary authoring environments.

Also as a side-project, I'm building a personal memex. (_who isn't?_ :man-shrugging:)

Anyway, I'm always up for a <https://twitter.com/ariaminaei|call> to bounce ideas :blush:

text: I remember seeing this blog post somehow a few months ago- I think you’re on to something as far as having executable content in a linked notes environment. My hacky patch has been iframing in web based tools that give you a free container somewhere like <http://repl.it|repl.it> or runkit, but I can’t use the results of the cell elsewhere like in an ObservableHQ notebook. Excited to follow along your project, and maybe contribute if I have more bandwidth someday :)

text:
I’ve long dreamed of taking JupyterLab (which moves away from the 1 vertical lane of cells that Jupyter Notebook had) and porting it into some kinda spatial / tiled environment so I can use it on a drafting table or maybe via paper programs (<https://paperprograms.org/>) etc

Screen Shot 2020-11-13 at 11.17.56 AM

text:
<@U01EHAE9D0W> hah, this is actually not terribly far off from what I'm planning to build next year
```(defn Lagrangian-action
  "Generates a scalar [[Action]] for the supplied path `q`
   in a system governed by the [[Lagrangian]] `L`."
  [L q t1 t2]
  ([[Calculus/definite-integral]]
     (compose L (Gamma q)) t1 t2))```
But with a layman audience b/c of it's structure hopefully.

text:
It's rather long, but the high points are
• Online textbooks are bad paper on screens, why not take advantage of the new hardware underpinnings
• Roam is *fantastic,* and everyone should use it. Why are textbooks linear anyway? 
• Examples are the way to go, and parameterized examples are better. Live examples are best. 
• (e.g. physics book where every single concept was encoded in a math language *in the book*, and the examples had clear dependencies to the formulas defined *in the book*)
• What happens when each function in the book has its own page with examples, definitions, code, worked math problems, etc...
• Allow users to put additional material in the book to expound on their thoughts 
• Crowd source better material over time - books don't need to be static. Look at wikipedia.
• Everyone learns different, so why force all to use the same book? Why not have multiple versions of each page tailored to different learning types?
